terms.definition: A paid training pathway where you learn on the job while completing required schooling.
terms.example: A first-year apprentice works with a journeyperson while logging hours and tasks.

terms.definition: A pay system based on set labour times rather than hourly time spent.
terms.example: A job pays 1.2 hours even if it takes longer or shorter.

terms.definition: A fully qualified tradesperson who has completed training and certification.
terms.example: The journeyperson signs off on your work and mentors you.

terms.definition: Behaviours that show you are reliable and respectful at work.
terms.example: Arrive on time, wear PPE, keep your bay clean, communicate clearly.

terms.definition: A Canadian standard that lets a certified tradesperson work across provinces/territories.
terms.example: A technician with Red Seal can apply for jobs in other provinces more easily.

terms.definition: A focused area of automotive work (e.g., electrical, driveline, brakes).
terms.example: A shop may have one tech who handles most diagnostic electrical issues.

terms.definition: The vehicle’s structural and mechanical base systems.
terms.example: Steering, suspension, brakes, and frame/structure.

terms.definition: Finding the cause of a problem using tests and evidence.
terms.example: Confirm a no-start is a battery issue using a multimeter and load test.

terms.definition: Parts that make and deliver power to move the vehicle.
terms.example: Engine + transmission + driveline components that turn the wheels.

terms.definition: Service done to prevent problems before they happen.
terms.example: Oil changes, inspections, tyre rotations, and fluid checks.

terms.definition: A category that tells you what type of fuel is burning.
terms.example: Use the correct extinguisher for fuel/oil fires, not just water.

terms.definition: Anything that can cause harm.
terms.example: A spinning fan, hot exhaust, or leaking fuel.

terms.definition: Thinking through what could go wrong and how to reduce it.
terms.example: Before lifting a vehicle, check lift points and stability.

terms.definition: A step-by-step method that reduces danger.
terms.example: Use a checklist before starting a grinder or hoist.

terms.definition: Moving air to reduce fumes and dust.
terms.example: Run exhaust extraction when a vehicle is idling indoors.

terms.definition: Work boots meeting safety standards (toe protection, etc.).
terms.example: Wear boots in the shop to prevent foot injuries from dropped tools.

terms.definition: A safety model: remove hazards first, PPE last.
terms.example: Use guards and procedures before relying on gloves alone.

terms.definition: Equipment worn to reduce injury risk.
terms.example: Safety glasses, gloves, hearing protection, and boots.

terms.definition: A mask that filters harmful particles or vapours.
terms.example: Wear one when sanding body filler or working with strong solvents.

terms.chapter: Chapter 05 — Vehicle Protection and Jack/Lift Safety
terms.definition: The balance point of an object’s weight.
terms.example: A vehicle must be positioned so it won’t tip on the hoist.

terms.chapter: Chapter 05 — Vehicle Protection and Jack/Lift Safety
terms.definition: A mechanism that holds a lift in place.
terms.example: Lower the lift onto the locks before working under the vehicle.

terms.chapter: Chapter 05 — Vehicle Protection and Jack/Lift Safety
terms.definition: A support stand used after lifting with a jack.
terms.example: After jacking a car, place stands before working underneath.

terms.chapter: Chapter 05 — Vehicle Protection and Jack/Lift Safety
terms.definition: A safe spot on a vehicle designed to support its weight.
terms.example: Use manufacturer lift points to avoid crushing rocker panels.

terms.definition: A part that holds components together (bolt, nut, screw).
terms.example: Choose the right fastener type and size for a bracket.

terms.definition: Tools used to loosen/tighten fasteners with a socket.
terms.example: Use the correct socket size to avoid rounding a nut.

terms.definition: Keeping tools clean and in good condition.
terms.example: Wipe down tools and return them to the correct storage spot.

terms.definition: A wrench that measures tightening force.
terms.example: Tighten lug nuts to the specified torque.

terms.definition: A tool for measuring inside/outside dimensions and depth.
terms.example: Measure brake rotor thickness or a bolt diameter.

terms.definition: A tool that measures small movement/runout.
terms.example: Check rotor runout or hub wobble.

terms.definition: Thin blades used to measure small gaps.
terms.example: Check spark plug gap or valve clearance (where applicable).

terms.definition: A precision tool for very accurate measurements.
terms.example: Measure crank journal diameter when checking engine wear.

terms.definition: The allowed amount a measurement can vary and still be acceptable.
terms.example: A rotor thickness must be above the minimum spec.

terms.definition: Safety covers that keep hands away from moving parts.
terms.example: A grinder guard helps prevent debris and contact injuries.

terms.definition: A high-torque tool for loosening/tightening fasteners.
terms.example: Remove wheel nuts quickly, then final-torque by hand.

terms.definition: A tool powered by compressed air.
terms.example: Use an air impact to remove lug nuts (with correct procedure).

terms.definition: A device that controls air pressure from a compressor.
terms.example: Set correct pressure before using air tools.

terms.definition: Damaging threads by starting a fastener at the wrong angle.
terms.example: A bolt that binds immediately may be cross-threaded—stop and inspect.

terms.definition: Tools used to cut or repair threads inside a hole (tap) or on a bolt (die).
terms.example: Chase damaged threads before reinstalling a bolt.

terms.definition: A coil or sleeve that restores threads in stripped holes.
terms.example: Repair stripped aluminium threads in a bracket or housing.

terms.definition: The spacing of threads on a bolt or nut.
terms.example: Match the correct nut to the bolt so it threads smoothly.

terms.definition: A liquid that helps prevent fasteners from loosening.
terms.example: Apply medium-strength threadlocker to bolts that vibrate loose.

terms.definition: Solving disagreements respectfully and effectively.
terms.example: Use calm language and focus on the task, not the person.

terms.definition: Taking appropriate action without being told every step.
terms.example: Restock rags or sweep your area when you notice it needs doing.

terms.definition: Being dependable and consistent.
terms.example: Finish tasks, follow instructions, and show up prepared.

terms.definition: Working well with others to meet a shared goal.
terms.example: Coordinate with another student to safely lift and support a vehicle.

terms.definition: The recommended timing for maintenance tasks.
terms.example: Oil change every set kilometres or months (per manual).

terms.definition: The manufacturer’s required tightening value.
terms.example: Look up and apply torque specs for drain plugs or wheel nuts.

terms.definition: A notice from a manufacturer about known issues and fixes.
terms.example: Check TSBs when a symptom is common on a specific model.

terms.definition: A unique identification number for a vehicle.
terms.example: Use VIN to confirm the correct parts and specifications.

terms.definition: A map of electrical circuits and connections.
terms.example: Trace a headlight circuit to find where voltage is lost.

terms.chapter: Chapter 07 — Strategy-Based Diagnosis and Repair Orders
terms.definition: Concern, Cause, Correction—standard repair documentation.
terms.example: Write: customer concern, your confirmed cause, and what you did to fix it.

terms.chapter: Chapter 07 — Strategy-Based Diagnosis and Repair Orders
terms.definition: A predicted cost and time for a repair.
terms.example: List parts and labour time before starting work.

terms.chapter: Chapter 07 — Strategy-Based Diagnosis and Repair Orders
terms.definition: A form that records the work requested and completed.
terms.example: Use the RO to record parts, labour, and notes.

terms.chapter: Chapter 07 — Strategy-Based Diagnosis and Repair Orders
terms.definition: The real reason the problem happened.
terms.example: A dead battery may be caused by a failing alternator, not just “battery bad.”

terms.chapter: Chapter 07 — Strategy-Based Diagnosis and Repair Orders
terms.definition: Confirming the problem exists and confirming the fix worked.
terms.example: Test drive before and after a brake repair.

terms.definition: Multi-point inspection: a structured check of key systems.
terms.example: Use a checklist to inspect tyres, fluids, lights, and leaks.

terms.definition: Ranking items by importance (safety first).
terms.example: Recommend brake repair before a cabin filter replacement.

terms.definition: Whether a part can safely keep being used.
terms.example: Measure rotor thickness to decide if it’s usable.

terms.definition: A sign that a part is worn out or near its limit.
terms.example: Tyre tread bars or brake pad wear indicators.

terms.definition: Paying close attention and confirming what you heard.
terms.example: Repeat the customer concern back to confirm details.

terms.definition: Customer approval to proceed with a repair.
terms.example: Get approval before installing parts or adding labour time.

terms.definition: Questions that reduce guesswork.
terms.example: Ask when the noise happens: cold start, braking, turning, etc.

terms.definition: Explaining technical ideas in everyday words.
terms.example: Instead of “caliper seized,” say “the brake is sticking and overheating.”

terms.definition: A standard that describes oil performance requirements.
terms.example: Choose oil that meets the required API/ILSAC spec.

terms.definition: A soft washer that seals a drain plug.
terms.example: Replace it to prevent leaks at the drain plug.

terms.definition: A valve that allows oil to flow if the filter is restricted.
terms.example: A clogged filter may trigger bypass to prevent oil starvation.

terms.definition: A reminder system that tracks maintenance needs.
terms.example: Reset the oil life monitor after an oil change.

terms.definition: How thick or thin a fluid is.
terms.example: Use the correct oil grade listed in the manual.

terms.definition: How much the air-fuel mix is squeezed before ignition.
terms.example: Higher compression can increase efficiency but may require higher-octane fuel.

terms.definition: Uncontrolled combustion that can damage an engine.
terms.example: A “pinging” sound under load can indicate detonation.

terms.definition: Intake, compression, power, exhaust—how many engines operate.
terms.example: Describe stroke order when explaining basic engine operation.

terms.definition: A measure of how quickly work is done.
terms.example: Higher horsepower supports higher speed and performance.

terms.definition: Turning force produced by the engine.
terms.example: Higher torque helps with acceleration and pulling power.

terms.definition: Measures cylinder pressure during cranking.
terms.example: Compare cylinder readings to find a weak cylinder.

terms.definition: Pressurizes a cylinder to find where air leaks out.
terms.example: Air at the intake suggests an intake valve leak.

terms.definition: Comparing cylinder performance quickly (often with scope/scan tools).
terms.example: Use to spot one cylinder that is much weaker than others.

terms.definition: Uses manifold vacuum to hint at engine condition.
terms.example: Low, unstable vacuum can indicate leaks or valve issues.

terms.definition: A passage that directs oil to engine parts.
terms.example: Blocked galleries can starve bearings of oil.

terms.definition: Resistance to oil flow in the lubrication system.
terms.example: Low oil pressure can indicate wear, low oil, or pump issues.

terms.definition: Moves oil through the engine.
terms.example: A worn pump may not maintain pressure at idle.

terms.definition: Limits maximum oil pressure.
terms.example: If stuck open, pressure may be low; if stuck closed, pressure may be high.

terms.definition: Correct blend of antifreeze and water.
terms.example: Use the right mixture to prevent freezing and overheating.

terms.definition: Raises boiling point by pressurizing the system.
terms.example: A weak cap can cause boil-over at normal temperatures.

terms.definition: Transfers heat from coolant to air.
terms.example: Blocked fins reduce cooling efficiency.

terms.definition: Controls coolant flow to maintain engine temperature.
terms.example: A stuck thermostat can cause overheating or slow warm-up.

terms.definition: Small back-and-forth movement that may be measured on bearings.
terms.example: Use a dial indicator if checking for play.

terms.definition: A small amount of tightening that removes looseness in a bearing.
terms.example: Set preload correctly to avoid overheating or play.

terms.definition: Keeps grease in and dirt/water out.
terms.example: Replace seals when servicing bearings.

terms.definition: A part that lets the wheel/hub rotate smoothly.
terms.example: A worn bearing can cause a growl that changes with speed.

terms.chapter: Chapter 11 — Heating, Brazing, Welding, and Cutting
terms.definition: Joining metal using a filler that melts ниже the base metal.
terms.example: Repair a small bracket using a brazing rod where appropriate.

terms.chapter: Chapter 11 — Heating, Brazing, Welding, and Cutting
terms.definition: Monitoring for sparks/embers after hot work.
terms.example: Check the area after cutting/grinding to prevent fires.

terms.chapter: Chapter 11 — Heating, Brazing, Welding, and Cutting
terms.definition: Area near a weld changed by heat.
terms.example: A large HAZ can weaken metal if overheated.

terms.chapter: Chapter 11 — Heating, Brazing, Welding, and Cutting
terms.definition: A common welding process using wire feed and shielding gas.
terms.example: Weld thin steel for a small repair with correct settings.

terms.chapter: Chapter 11 — Heating, Brazing, Welding, and Cutting
terms.definition: How deeply the weld fuses into the metal.
terms.example: A strong weld shows proper penetration without burn-through.

terms.definition: A structured checklist to inspect key vehicle systems.
terms.example: Complete an MPI sheet during an oil service and note urgent items.

terms.definition: How urgent a repair is (safety, soon, monitor).
terms.example: Brake line leak = safety; cabin filter = non-urgent.

terms.definition: When a maintenance task should be done based on time or kilometres.
terms.example: Use the schedule to recommend a transmission service at the right time.

terms.definition: Checking parts using sight (and basic checks) without disassembly.
terms.example: Look for cracked belts, leaks, and uneven tyre wear.

terms.definition: The tyre edge that seals against the wheel rim.
terms.example: Use correct technique to seat the bead safely during mounting.

terms.definition: Tightening fasteners to the manufacturer value.
terms.example: Torque wheel nuts in a star pattern to the correct spec.

terms.definition: Tyre Pressure Monitoring System that warns about low pressure.
terms.example: Reset or relearn TPMS after tyre service when required.

terms.definition: The order you move tyres to different corners.
terms.example: Rotate front-to-rear to reduce uneven wear (as recommended).

terms.definition: Adding weights to stop vibration caused by uneven mass.
terms.example: Balance a wheel after mounting new tyres.

terms.definition: A valve that allows flow when a filter is restricted.
terms.example: Understand why an engine may still get oil if the filter clogs.

terms.definition: Unwanted material in oil/coolant (fuel, coolant, metal, dirt).
terms.example: Milky oil may indicate coolant contamination.

terms.definition: A measurement related to resistance to oil flow.
terms.example: Investigate low oil pressure warning using test gauge procedures.

terms.definition: How thick or thin oil is at a given temperature.
terms.example: Choose the oil grade listed on the oil cap or service info.

terms.definition: Trapped air that reduces cooling and can cause hot spots.
terms.example: Bleed air using the correct bleeding procedure.

terms.definition: Blend of antifreeze and water for freezing/boiling protection.
terms.example: Test mixture with a refractometer or tester.

terms.definition: Cap that pressurizes the system to raise boiling point.
terms.example: Replace a weak cap causing boil-over.

terms.definition: Temperature-controlled valve regulating coolant flow.
terms.example: A stuck thermostat can cause overheating or slow warm-up.

terms.definition: Removing air from the cooling system after service.
terms.example: Use bleeder screws or vacuum fill tools where available.

terms.definition: Replacing old coolant and cleaning the system.
terms.example: Drain, flush, refill with the correct coolant type.

terms.definition: Electrical corrosion that can damage cooling components.
terms.example: Check for stray voltage if corrosion is recurring.

terms.definition: Small radiator inside the cabin used for heat.
terms.example: A clogged heater core can cause poor cabin heat.

terms.definition: Testing the cooling system for leaks under pressure.
terms.example: Use a pressure tester to find a slow coolant leak.

terms.definition: System that captures fuel vapours so they are not released.
terms.example: Diagnose an EVAP leak code with a smoke test.

terms.definition: How fuel moves from tank to engine.
terms.example: Trace pump → lines → filter → rail/injectors.

terms.definition: Pressure in the fuel system needed for correct operation.
terms.example: Use a gauge or scan data to confirm spec pressure.

terms.definition: Gasoline Direct Injection—fuel injected directly into the cylinder.
terms.example: Discuss carbon buildup risks and service implications.

terms.definition: Device that sprays fuel into the engine.
terms.example: Diagnose a misfire caused by a clogged injector.

terms.definition: Resistance to exhaust flow.
terms.example: A restricted catalytic converter can reduce power.

terms.definition: The path air takes into the engine.
terms.example: Check for intake leaks after a rough idle complaint.

terms.definition: Sensor measuring incoming air mass.
terms.example: A dirty MAF can cause poor fuel economy or drivability issues.

terms.definition: Controls airflow into the engine.
terms.example: Clean carbon buildup to address sticky throttle symptoms.

terms.definition: Uses exhaust energy to compress intake air.
terms.example: Explain boost and check for charge-air leaks.

terms.chapter: Chapter 33 — Hybrid and CVT Transmissions (support reading)
terms.definition: Continuously Variable Transmission—changes ratios without fixed gears.
terms.example: Discuss belt/chain CVT operation and service cautions.

terms.chapter: Chapter 33 — Hybrid and CVT Transmissions (support reading)
terms.definition: Vehicle using both an internal combustion engine and electric drive.
terms.example: Identify high-voltage components and orange cables.

terms.chapter: Chapter 33 — Hybrid and CVT Transmissions (support reading)
terms.definition: Converts DC battery power to AC for the motor (and back).
terms.example: Recognize inverter cooling and safety considerations.

terms.chapter: Chapter 33 — Hybrid and CVT Transmissions (support reading)
terms.definition: Using the motor to slow the vehicle and recharge the battery.
terms.example: Explain why brake feel can differ on hybrids.

terms.definition: Compressed Natural Gas fuel system.
terms.example: Identify high-pressure tanks and required safety steps.

terms.definition: Vehicle that can run on gasoline and ethanol blends.
terms.example: Confirm ethanol content if drivability issues occur.

terms.definition: Rules and procedures for safe fuel containment.
terms.example: Use correct ventilation and avoid ignition sources during service.

terms.definition: Liquefied petroleum gas fuel system.
terms.example: Know shutoff valves and leak-check procedures.

terms.definition: Ignition coil mounted on each spark plug.
terms.example: Swap coils to confirm a coil-related misfire.

terms.definition: A cylinder that is not burning properly.
terms.example: Use scan tool misfire counters and confirm with tests.

terms.definition: High-voltage side of the ignition system.
terms.example: Look for arcing marks on coils and boots.

terms.definition: Distance the spark must jump at the plug.
terms.example: Set or verify gap where applicable before installation.

terms.definition: When the spark occurs relative to piston position.
terms.example: Use scan data to check timing changes under load.

terms.definition: Device that reduces harmful exhaust gases.
terms.example: A restricted converter can cause loss of power and codes.

terms.definition: Exhaust Gas Recirculation—reduces NOx by lowering combustion temps.
terms.example: Stuck EGR can cause rough idle or pinging.

terms.definition: Measures oxygen in exhaust for fuel control feedback.
terms.example: A lazy O2 sensor can cause poor fuel economy.

terms.definition: Positive Crankcase Ventilation—routes crankcase vapours back to intake.
terms.example: A clogged PCV can cause oil leaks or sludge.

terms.definition: OBD tests that must complete before inspection.
terms.example: Drive cycle completes monitors after battery disconnect.

terms.definition: Flow of electricity through a circuit.
terms.example: Check starter draw when diagnosing slow crank.

terms.definition: Return path for current, usually the vehicle chassis.
terms.example: Clean a corroded ground to fix intermittent electrical faults.

terms.definition: Opposition to current flow.
terms.example: High resistance in a connection causes heat and voltage drop.

terms.definition: How components are connected in a circuit.
terms.example: Identify why one bulb out can affect others (series) or not (parallel).

terms.definition: Electrical pressure that pushes current.
terms.example: Measure battery voltage to confirm state of charge.

terms.chapter: Chapter 57 — Electrical Components and Wiring Repair
terms.definition: Plug that joins wiring harness sections.
terms.example: Inspect for bent pins or water intrusion.

terms.chapter: Chapter 57 — Electrical Components and Wiring Repair
terms.definition: Compressing a terminal onto wire for a solid connection.
terms.example: Use a proper crimper instead of pliers.

terms.chapter: Chapter 57 — Electrical Components and Wiring Repair
terms.definition: Tubing that shrinks to seal and protect repairs.
terms.example: Seal a splice after repair to prevent corrosion.

terms.chapter: Chapter 57 — Electrical Components and Wiring Repair
terms.definition: Joining wires with melted solder (where appropriate).
terms.example: Solder a repair if procedure requires it, then seal properly.

terms.chapter: Chapter 57 — Electrical Components and Wiring Repair
terms.definition: Wire size (thickness) affecting current capacity.
terms.example: Use the correct gauge when repairing a harness.

terms.chapter: Chapter 58 — Meter Usage and Circuit Diagnosis
terms.definition: Testing a connector without damaging it.
terms.example: Probe from the back of the connector to read sensor voltage.

terms.chapter: Chapter 58 — Meter Usage and Circuit Diagnosis
terms.definition: Whether a circuit path is unbroken.
terms.example: Confirm a wire is intact from switch to load.

terms.chapter: Chapter 58 — Meter Usage and Circuit Diagnosis
terms.definition: Testing a circuit/component under working conditions.
terms.example: Use a test light to confirm a circuit can carry current.

terms.chapter: Chapter 58 — Meter Usage and Circuit Diagnosis
terms.definition: Tool that measures voltage, resistance, and more.
terms.example: Check for battery voltage at a fuse.

terms.chapter: Chapter 58 — Meter Usage and Circuit Diagnosis
terms.definition: Testing how much voltage is lost across a connection.
terms.example: Find a bad ground by measuring voltage drop while loaded.

terms.definition: Battery’s ability to crank in cold conditions.
terms.example: Compare measured capacity to rated CCA.

terms.definition: Electrical draw when the vehicle is off.
terms.example: Measure draw if a battery keeps going dead overnight.

terms.definition: How full a battery is.
terms.example: Use a tester to confirm battery charge before diagnosis.

terms.definition: Crystal buildup reducing battery capacity.
terms.example: A neglected battery may fail load testing due to sulfation.

terms.definition: Battery voltage while the starter is operating.
terms.example: Low cranking voltage may indicate weak battery or high resistance.

terms.definition: Prevents starting unless in Park/Neutral.
terms.example: No-crank in Drive suggests switch/adjustment issue.

terms.definition: Switch that engages the starter and connects high current.
terms.example: A click with no crank can indicate solenoid issues.

terms.definition: Test for excessive resistance in cables/connections.
terms.example: Measure drop across positive cable during cranking.

terms.definition: Unwanted alternating current in DC charging output.
terms.example: Use a meter/scope to check ripple if electronics act up.

terms.definition: Generates electricity to run the vehicle and charge the battery.
terms.example: Diagnose low charging voltage with a charging test.

terms.definition: System voltage while running (typical range varies).
terms.example: Confirm charging voltage is within spec at idle and with load.

terms.definition: Electrical one-way valve inside alternator rectifier.
terms.example: A bad diode can cause AC ripple and battery drain.

terms.definition: Controls alternator output voltage.
terms.example: A failed regulator may overcharge and damage the battery.

terms.definition: Lighting controlled by modules and network messages.
terms.example: A scan tool may be needed to diagnose module-controlled lamps.

terms.definition: Fuses/relays that prevent damage from overloads.
terms.example: Replace a blown fuse only after finding the cause.

terms.definition: Return side of the circuit.
terms.example: A bad ground can make lights flicker.

terms.definition: An electrically controlled switch.
terms.example: Use a relay to power headlights without overloading a switch.

terms.definition: Loss of voltage due to resistance.
terms.example: Dim lights can be caused by corroded connectors causing voltage drop.

terms.chapter: Chapter 64 — Network Communications and Body Accessories
terms.definition: A device that moves/does work (motor, solenoid).
terms.example: Door lock actuator failing causes locks not to work.

terms.chapter: Chapter 64 — Network Communications and Body Accessories
terms.definition: A network that lets vehicle modules share data.
terms.example: Diagnose communication codes or module dropouts.

terms.chapter: Chapter 64 — Network Communications and Body Accessories
terms.definition: Port where scan tools plug in.
terms.example: Connect a scan tool to read codes and live data.

terms.chapter: Chapter 64 — Network Communications and Body Accessories
terms.definition: A computer that controls a system (BCM, PCM, etc.).
terms.example: A BCM controls body functions like locks and lighting.

terms.chapter: Chapter 64 — Network Communications and Body Accessories
terms.definition: How modules are connected on the network.
terms.example: A short on the bus can take down multiple systems.

terms.definition: Leverage advantage built into pedal design.
terms.example: More pedal travel can mean more leverage.

terms.definition: Lights/messages showing faults or wear.
terms.example: Investigate brake warning light before road testing.

terms.definition: Resistance that slows the vehicle when pads/shoes press on a surface.

terms.definition: Uses fluid pressure to move brake components.
terms.example: Brake pedal force becomes fluid pressure at the calipers.

terms.definition: Anti-lock braking system preventing wheel lockup.

terms.chapter: Chapter 48 — Hydraulics and Power Brakes Theory
terms.definition: Hydraulic fluid designed for braking systems.

terms.chapter: Chapter 48 — Hydraulics and Power Brakes Theory
terms.definition: Creates hydraulic pressure when you press the pedal.

terms.chapter: Chapter 48 — Hydraulics and Power Brakes Theory
terms.definition: Pressure in a confined fluid transmits equally in all directions.

terms.definition: Removing air from brake lines.

terms.chapter: Chapter 49 — Servicing the Hydraulic System and Power Brakes
terms.definition: Metal tubing carrying brake fluid.

terms.chapter: Chapter 49 — Servicing the Hydraulic System and Power Brakes
terms.definition: Rubber hose allowing movement at wheels.
terms.example: Collapsed hose can cause a dragging brake.

terms.chapter: Chapter 49 — Servicing the Hydraulic System and Power Brakes
terms.definition: Replacing old brake fluid to remove moisture.
terms.example: Flush fluid to reduce corrosion and improve performance.

terms.chapter: Chapter 49 — Servicing the Hydraulic System and Power Brakes
terms.definition: Testing vacuum supply to booster.
terms.example: Low vacuum can reduce brake assist.

terms.definition: Sensor target used to read wheel speed.
terms.example: Damaged ring can trigger ABS faults.

terms.definition: Holds pads and squeezes rotor.

terms.definition: Device/sound showing pads are worn.
terms.example: Squeal can indicate wear indicator contact.

terms.definition: Disc the pads clamp onto.

terms.definition: Side-to-side wobble of the rotor.

terms.chapter: Chapter 51 — Servicing the Disc Brake System
terms.definition: Procedure to seat pads and rotors properly.
terms.example: Perform controlled stops after brake service.

terms.chapter: Chapter 51 — Servicing the Disc Brake System
terms.definition: Clips/shims that support pads and reduce noise.

terms.chapter: Chapter 51 — Servicing the Disc Brake System
terms.definition: Special grease for slides and contact points.

terms.chapter: Chapter 51 — Servicing the Disc Brake System
terms.definition: Order and method of tightening fasteners.
terms.example: Torque caliper bracket bolts and wheel nuts correctly.

terms.definition: Inside size of brake drum (has max spec).

terms.definition: Two shoes with different roles in drum braking.

terms.definition: Mechanism that maintains correct shoe-to-drum clearance.
terms.example: A seized adjuster causes low pedal or poor braking.

terms.definition: Hydraulic cylinder pushing shoes outward.

terms.chapter: Chapter 53 — Servicing the Drum Brake System
terms.definition: Setting shoe clearance for proper pedal feel.
terms.example: Adjust drums so there is slight drag then recheck.

terms.chapter: Chapter 53 — Servicing the Drum Brake System
terms.definition: Solvent for removing brake dust and grease.
